inventory.commentary: Includes idioms (figurative extensions of Sense 1) foot_in_the_door, on_one's_feet, off_one's_feet, at_the_feet

sense.name: the lowest anatomical appendage of organisms, used for locomotion
sense.examples: Bob had his foot in a cast for six weeks. Mary pulled a thorn out of her dog's foot. Snails can crawl by means of their single muscular foot. The crowd got to their feet as the batter hit a grand slam home run over the fence. The disciples bowed at the feet of their guru. (literally genuflecting in front of his feet) While he was playing in the water, a big wave knocked the child off his feet. Bob stuck his foot in the door of the elevator before it closed, so we could get in.

sense.name: a unit of length
sense.examples: There are twelve inches in one foot. John is six feet tall. The car skidded about a hundred feet before hitting a tree.

sense.name: the end, or lower, position of an object
sense.commentary: FOOT[+relation][+position][+location][+end/+bottom] Note: usually occurs in the singular
sense.examples: Watch out for the bucket at the foot of the stairs. A small village is nestled at the foot of the mountain. We are standing at the foot of the most famous tower in Italy. The guest of honor should not be seated at the foot of the table, but at the head. A cedar chest was placed at the foot of the bed.

sense.name: travel by walking
sense.examples: She was fleet of foot. (a fast walker) We'll have to travel on foot over the roughest terrain.

sense.name: support structures of objects that resemble appendages
sense.examples: He put casters on the feet of the chairs. (wheels attached so the chair rolls) Guide the fabric through the foot of the sewing machine as you stitch. The statue's left foot was broken off.

sense.name: a metrical unit in poetry
sense.examples: Each line of this poem has five metrical feet. In English, a poetic foot is characterized by stressed and unstressed syllables. In classical ancient poetry, a foot was measured by long and short syllables.

sense.name: infantry, soldiers who walk to battle
sense.examples: "There were ten thousand horsemen and as many fully-armed foot"

sense.name: a member of a surveillance team, a spy
sense.examples: He served as a foot on that undercover mission.

sense.name: the first step towards a goal
sense.examples: This internship will help Mary's son get a foot in the door in the world of finance. It's very difficult to get a foot in the door in show business.

sense.name: a state of recovery or recuperation
sense.examples: These loans will help the firm get back on its feet economically. There is a temp in our office until the regular receptionist gets back on her feet after surgery.

sense.name: in an ad lib or extemporaneous manner
sense.examples: You have to be able to think on your feet in that job. John is a careful analyst but he is not fast on his feet with decision making.

sense.name: enamored of, emotionally swept away
sense.examples: The sultry Austrian film star swept the men off their feet. Let's not get swept off our feet by this economic news just yet.

sense.name: be under the spell or influence of something
sense.examples: They worship at the feet of the almighty dollar. They refuse to grovel at the feet of more powerful nations.
